pros: Kind, dedicated faculty with great resources for adjunct professors.
cons: Salary a bit lower than other universities.

pros: Beautiful campus and amazing students and faculty.
cons: Everything else. Low pay, long hours, no work-life balance or good boundaries. Had 5 supervisors in 3 years, none of them stuck around for more than a few months, they were overworked and underpaid. Toxic environment, top-down. Administration doesn't listen to students, faculty, or their own staff. As employees leave, responsibilities get passed down to those who stay, with no pay increase.

pros: Small community of peers Not up and out system
cons: Administration is not transparent HR is awful and frequently makes errors with pay

review_title: I can’t afford to work there.
pros: Great location, great mission, great students
cons: Base salaries for faculty are far below the median.

pros: Strong historic mission and amazing students. Some really great peers who are totally dedicated to the success of students. The faculty are innovative, kind, committed, compassionate, and focused on helping students achieve their dreams.
cons: Top down toxic management, resulting in a fear based silence. Some units are not student focused and create dysfunction. High turnover of great staff and those who could make a difference, but leave once they see behind the curtain. Low salaries, no increases and pitiful retirement.

pros: Friendly coworkers, generous PTO, decent overall benefits, minimal stress.
cons: Low pay and no room for advancement.

pros: Love the colleagues I work with. Students are awesome!
cons: Faculty are asked to do a lot with little compensation.

pros: The whole staff across functional units all have a profound focus on student's success.
cons: The overwhelming focus on students can distract the university's focus on it's organizational future.

pros: Some great colleagues but the good ones leave quickly
cons:
Pay is low
Growth opportunities limited

pros: Friendly work environment around campus
cons: I don’t have many cons. Good place to work. Salary could be better

pros: The people are great to work with
cons: very political and decisions take a lot of time to get made

pros: Flexibility, good work environment, location
cons: Top-down administration, lack of engagement

pros: Discounted education if employment continues
cons: Minimum wage for exceeded workload.

pros: Cool evenrionment. Decent ppl to work with
cons: Leadership does not have a clear direction and micro management

job_title: Unified Communications Specialist in Baltimore, MD
pros: Friendly community, Family oriented, Job security
cons: Very little room for growth

pros: Superiors are nice and understanding
cons: Some higher ups are close minded

pros: Student workers on campus are a boon to the campus and the student. There are a variety of options and hours are flexible. I worked in the career center and gained valuable administrative skills. It was convenient to work on campus. The pay was not high, but more than minimum wage. Overall, a good opportunity for a student to gain experience and extra money. Campus is in a great location.
cons: The cons are very minor. The administrative at NDM is not well-organized and it occasionally causes problems or issues. Student workers, however, are only minimally effective by this dysfunction. Also, this is an impression from several years ago. The president of the university is new and things could be smoother.

pros: Beautiful campus grounds, committed faculty, ratio of faculty to student is very good.
cons:
There is much talk about values but not much evidence of them. The hierarchy is ridiculous and many decisions seem to be made behind closed doors by just two or three administrators. HR must not be doing background checks as a recent report in Baltimore media  indicated a sexual abuser was in charge of the office of student affairs for many years. 
More recent alumni told me they often paid to eat off campus because the food was  horrible in the dining hall.

pros: The tradition of School Sisters is excellent. The mission-driven aspect is really sold to potential employees and students.
cons: While at Notre Dame of Maryland University, I learned to how to look out for myself. Offices try too hard to work independently and most will throw you under the bus at first chance, especially as a new employee. Or, if you've been there for an even small amount of time, getting blamed for things you didn't do has also occurred. Hierarchy here is everything, and if you aren't at least a director, it seems unlikely that you will have much of a say in anything. Always having to live with someone else's decision for your job without any voice is absolutely present.

job_title: Graduate Residence Coordinator in Baltimore, MD
pros:
-The students are a bit different from students at a bigger university but they are very loving and academic focused. 
-The community is aesthetically pleasing. 
-They are very inclusive...seemingly. Depending on your intersections, it may vary. 
-The institution looks good from the outside looking in.
cons:
- Stipend was below national & state average set at $7k for the year!! May have gone up $1k since I have left, but it still is below cost of living. 
- You are overworked & underpaid
-No support for lower level administration/staff
-Often treated as though you were not a part of the community due to this position being a graduate position yet it held the responsibility of a full-time staff member. In essence, you were treated as if you were expendable.
-Microaggressions are preached against, but used on a daily basis with no concern.
-After some time working there, one will notice that the institution & its employee are actually bitter and complains about small things often. 
-Resources are minimal to none.
-Student Life Staff assistants spend time talking about their colleagues to students instead of helping to advance/improve morale. 
-Turnover is extremely high.
-The "suite" they offer is located next door to students while the Director and student life program assistant are housed in the RD apartments. This offers no privacy which makes it difficult to maintain a work/life balance, and makes one question the institution's financial state since they offer housing for positions which typically are not housed on-site. 
-The position comes with a meal plan to the campus dining hall which has often made students and staff members sick. 
-Morale is super low and favoritism plays a big part in what one can do and how one advances.

pros: Hmmm, beautiful campus, SSNDs are lovely people
cons: Hierarchical! Though I've worked in corporate and private environments I have never worked somewhere that was less willing to include employees in decision making, and this is a place that touts inclusivity and decision sharing. The Enrollment and Development offices seem to foster and reward mediocrity; lowering the school’s standards for student acceptance, producing promotional materials that lack a clear position and are poorly executed, a web site that is riddled with misspellings and inaccuracies, and staff retention averaging one year. It's no wonder that enrollment continues to decline and that alumni giving is down.

pros: This is a good place to work if you share an appreciation for the mission and history of NDMU. The sense of spirit and teamwork can be very strong.
cons: If you don't share an appreciation for the mission, it's very easy to feel underwhelmed and overworked.

pros: Aesthetics / Environment ...  Beautiful Campus
cons: Absolutely no training.  Gross lack of leadership.  Too happy to blame staff for any inaccuracies.  I was just disgusted at how the management staff talked negatively about each other AND their staff.  Definitely watch for red flags if you are seeking a position here!  The college itself is wonderful...

job_title: Assistant to the Assistant Athletic Director in Towson, MD
pros: Super flexible schedule, I could literally pick any time I wanted to do the work and it was no problem. Also, I was not managed heavily so I could do the projects how I wanted to.
cons: There wasn't really that much for me to do or an organized way of telling me what projects I had to do.

pros: Mission-oriented. Great students. Devoted faculty. Good benefits.
cons: Backstabbing. No professional development. Broken HR system. Meat grinder atmosphere. No respect. Staff treated like dogs.

job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in Baltimore, MD
pros: Lots of PTO days, free yoga,and personal training.
cons: The cons would be low pay, however Higher Ed is a low paying industry(at least for staff, I can't speak for faculty positions) That is why Universities offer so much PTO and other benefits. To me 30 plus days off is worth more than money.

review_title: resume builder not a place to grow a career
pros:
flexible schedule
some nice folks to work with
cons:
very low salary
horrible upper management
lack of effective or professional communication skills

pros: Great people (for the most part), nice campus area, free parking
cons: Very demanding staff, never enough money in the budget for growth,  many employees underpaid, lacks classrooms with reliable technology

pros: Excellent colleagues who really care about students.
cons: Get penalized for low enrolled courses.

review_title: Great to work, not to learn
job_title: Student Life Information Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: Small school with young people working.  Friendly atmosphere.  Easy scheduling for student workers.
cons: There was a level of professionalism that wasn't there.  Too much is expected of student works for minimum pay.

job_title: Director of A Student Life Office in Baltimore, MD
pros: Wonderful opportunity to build resume.
cons: The university is still developing itself, often responsibilities blurred. Often staff get burnt out and do not last. Turn-over rate is high.

pros: PTO, benefits, good starting job to gain experience, beautiful campus, and people are very nice.
cons: Lack of leadership, no room to grow, low salaries, disorganized, work a lot of over time, not enough parking.

pros:
Freedom to complete the work
Encouraged professional development
Nice location
cons: Lack of financial responsibility in business office

pros: Gaining experience and the benefits.
cons: Low Pay and co-workers. Both less than satisfactory.

pros: class sizes, community feel, and approachable upper admin
cons: pay. especially pay increase for promotion and tenure

job_title: Head Athletic Trainer in Baltimore, MD
pros: Work in an environment that values open communication and teamwork
cons: Due to the size of the institution there is a challenge with finances, however that is expected.

pros: Collaborative community- other faculty great to work with.
cons: Administration makes decisions without faculty input.

pros: Time off. community unity. Thats it.
cons: being treated like crap on a regular basis

pros: Some the people and students
cons: People not wanting to work with you

pros: faculty were very helpful and polite
